Description: Improve the accuracy and intelligence of item pricing across all item types. Covers mod classification improvements; ilvl awareness; resistance valuation; calibration bootstrapping; and synergy detection.

Different equipment slots have different ilvl breakpoints for top-tier mods (e.g. bows need ilvl 82 for top phys% but wands only need 81). Build per-slot breakpoint tables and factor ilvl into loot filter tiering for exceptional bases. Data source: RePoE mod tiers.

Current common mod classification is heuristic-based and may occasionally misclassify an unusual valuable mod as 'common'. Investigate data-driven approaches: use RePoE tier data to determine if a mod is valuable based on its tier rank rather than pattern matching. Consider using the mod_database weight table as the source of truth.

Unusual 'Grants Skill:' formats might not be stripped by _SKIP_LINE_RE in trade_client.py and could leak into trade queries. Audit all skill grant formats in the game data and expand the regex to cover edge cases.

High resistance rolls add real value beyond what the trade query captures. If a resist mod is above 40% (fire/cold/lightning) or 20% (chaos) calculate a sum-of-mod-value bonus and factor it into the score. Could be a multiplier or flat addition to help differentiate e.g. a ring with 43% fire res from one with 20%.

Ship a curated calibration.jsonl with the repo so new users get reasonable price estimates from day one. Consider league-aware shards since calibration data from one league may not apply to another. Update periodically as more data is collected.

Certain mod combinations are worth more together than the sum of their parts (e.g. %increased phys + flat phys on weapons or +life + all res on jewelry). Detect known synergy pairs and apply a score multiplier when both are present.

Summary: Add jewel and charm scoring support
Description: Jewels and charms have different valuable mod pools than equipment. Extend mod_database weight tables to cover jewel-specific mods (e.g. crit multi; life; damage) and charm-specific mods (duration; effect). Currently these item classes may get inaccurate grades.

Summary: Add influence and fractured mod value recognition
Description: Fractured mods lock a guaranteed roll which significantly increases item value. Influence mods (if POE2 adds them) similarly add value. Score_item should apply a bonus multiplier when fractured mods are present especially for T1-T2 fractured rolls.
Make the price overlay more visually appealing and informative. Covers currency icons; game-native styling; celebration effects; and improved dismiss/scrap indicators.

Summary: Show currency icons next to price text
Description: Display small currency images (Divine; Exalted; Chaos orb icons) next to the price text in the overlay instead of just the currency name string. Makes prices instantly recognizable at a glance. Will need to bundle small PNG sprites and render them in tkinter.
When a chanceable normal base is detected show a Chance Orb icon and the target unique's icon/art in the overlay alongside the text. Visual support for the existing chanceable base detection feature.
Current ✗ dismiss is plain Unicode in grey. Explore nicer options: custom icon; styled background; subtle animation; or a brief flash before disappearing. Should be quick to read but not distracting.

Summary: Add scrap indicator for quality/socketed dismissed items
Description: Items dismissed as ✗ that have quality% or sockets should show a scrap/hammer icon instead reminding players to break them down for etchers; armour scraps; whetstones; baubles; gemcutters. These crafting materials are valuable for upgrades and currency exchange.

Make the price overlay look like part of the POE2 game UI — matching fonts (FontinSmallCaps or similar); dark translucent panel styling; gold/brown borders similar to tooltip frames. Even though it's a separate overlay it should feel integrated.

Stronger visual feedback when something is high value. Ideas: particle/glow effects around the price tag; brief screen-edge flash; optional sound alert (cha-ching). Should be toggleable. The rainbow mirror-tier effect already exists — extend for other thresholds.

Summary: Add compact vs expanded overlay mode
Description: Toggle between a compact mode (just price + grade) and an expanded mode (price + grade + top mods + tier breakdown + DPS/defense). Compact is default for speed; expanded for learning. Could be triggered by holding Shift while hovering.

Summary: Show mod tier labels in expanded overlay
Description: In expanded overlay mode show T1/T2/T3 labels next to each mod line. Uses the existing mod_database tier ladder data. Helps players learn which mods are the valuable ones driving the grade.
Transform from bat-file scripts into a proper Windows desktop application with system tray; settings GUI; auto-launch; installer; and auto-updater.

Minimize to system tray instead of keeping a console window open. Tray icon should show status (active/paused/error). Right-click menu: Show Console; Settings; Pause/Resume; Exit. Double-click to show/hide console.

Replace SETTINGS.bat with a proper tkinter or PyQt settings window. Sections: League selection; overlay appearance (colors; font size; duration; position offset); hotkey configuration; loot filter settings; advanced (scan FPS; API rate limits). Save to a config file that main.py reads on startup.

Detect when POE2 launches and automatically start the overlay. Options: Windows Task Scheduler trigger; lightweight tray service that polls for PathOfExile2.exe; or Windows WMI process creation events. Should also auto-pause when POE2 exits.

Build a proper installer using NSIS; Inno Setup; or PyInstaller+NSIS. Should handle Python bundling (or detect existing Python); create Start Menu shortcut; optionally add to startup; set up file associations. Removes the 'install Python and Git' barrier for new users.

Check GitHub releases on startup for new versions. Show a notification if an update is available with a one-click update button. Could use GitHub API to compare version tags. Should handle the update gracefully (download; extract; restart).

Current launcher.py has basic first-run flow. Enhance with: visual league selector (with league icons/dates); account name entry for trade API; overlay position test (show sample price tag and let user drag it); brief feature tour.
Build comprehensive automated testing and CI/CD pipeline. Covers migration to pytest; regression suites for all major components; and cross-platform validation.

Current test_pipeline.py and mod_database.py self-tests are ad-hoc. Migrate to proper pytest with fixtures; parametrized tests; and clear pass/fail reporting. Set up conftest.py with shared fixtures for mock items; parsed mods; etc.

Extend the existing 34 test cases into a comprehensive regression suite covering: all grade boundaries (S/A/B/C/JUNK); DPS factor curves; defense factor curves; weight table edge cases; unknown mod fallback; per-item-class behavior. Target: 100+ test cases.

Test suite for mod_parser.py: regex compilation coverage; mod text → stat_id matching accuracy; value extraction; mod_type preservation (rune stays rune; fractured stays fractured). Use real clipboard samples from the debug archive as fixtures.

Test suite for item_parser.py: parsing all item classes (weapons; armor; jewelry; currency; gems; maps); edge cases (unidentified; corrupted; mirrored; fractured); section separator handling; DPS and defense extraction accuracy.

Test suite for trade_client.py: query JSON structure validation; progressive search strategy; common mod filtering; value-dependent minimums; DPS/defense equipment_filters; outlier trimming; rate limiting behavior. Mock the HTTP layer.

Full pipeline tests: clipboard text → parse → score → price lookup → overlay display text. Use archived clipboard captures as input and validate the complete output chain. Should catch regressions in the interaction between components.
Configure CI to run the full test suite on every push and PR. Include: pytest run; linting (ruff or flake8); type checking (mypy optional). Badge in README showing build status.

Test and document behavior across different setups: 1080p; 1440p; 4K; ultrawide; multi-monitor with various DPI settings. The overlay positioning and screen boundary detection in overlay.py need validation. Create a test matrix.
Enhance the loot filter auto-updater with smarter economy-driven tiering; user overrides; and better UX around filter changes.

Current filter tiering uses broad category thresholds. Add per-base-type awareness so e.g. a Heavy Belt (chanceable to Headhunter) gets special treatment even though 'normal belts' as a category are hidden.

Let users pin specific items to always-show or always-hide regardless of economy data. Persist overrides in a local config file. Useful for SSF players or niche builds that value items differently from the trade economy.

Summary: Add filter diff preview before applying
Description: Before writing the updated filter show the user a summary of what changed: items promoted; items demoted; new items added. Let them approve or reject the update. Could be a console summary or a GUI diff view.

Allow users to maintain multiple filter profiles (e.g. Strict; Semi-Strict; Relaxed) that all get economy-updated. Each profile has different base thresholds but the same economy data drives the tiering.

After updating the filter file notify the user to reload in-game. If possible detect when the game has reloaded the filter (file access timestamp) and confirm. Show a brief overlay notification: 'Filter updated — reload in game'.
Give users control over how the tool behaves and displays information. Covers mod classification UI; hotkey customization; display preferences; and per-league profiles.

Expose the common/key/premium mod weight lists as a toggleable UI (checkboxes or radio buttons per mod). Lets users override defaults; adapt to meta shifts; and adjust per-league without code changes. Addresses the 'we can not be right for everyone' problem with heuristic classification.

Let users rebind the scan trigger (currently cursor-stop-based Ctrl+C); deep query (Ctrl+Shift+C); and bug report (Ctrl+Shift+B) hotkeys. Store in config file. Validate no conflicts with game bindings.
Let users choose their preferred price display: Divine only; Chaos only; both; or auto (divine for expensive items; chaos for cheap). Currently hardcoded thresholds in price_cache.py and config.py.

Let users set minimum value thresholds for when the overlay appears. E.g. 'only show for items worth 1+ divine' to reduce noise while mapping. Could have different thresholds for different activities (mapping vs stash sorting).
When switching leagues auto-load league-specific settings (different filter profiles; calibration data; price thresholds). Useful when playing both trade and SSF or standard vs league.
Add stash tab scanning and value tracking features for bulk item management.

Summary: Add bulk stash tab scanning mode
Description: Scan an entire stash tab by moving cursor across all item slots systematically. Could be manual (user moves cursor) with rapid-fire Ctrl+C or semi-automated (tool moves cursor in a grid pattern). Show running value total.

After scanning a stash tab show a summary: total estimated value; breakdown by grade (S/A/B/C items); top 5 most valuable items; count of junk items to vendor. Could be a console table or a GUI panel.

Summary: Add price tag persistence for scanned items
Description: Remember prices for items in specific stash positions so returning to a previously-scanned tab shows cached prices instantly without re-querying. Key by stash tab name + grid position + item hash.

Summary: Add stash tab value tracking over time
Description: Track the total value of scanned stash tabs over time. Show a simple trend: 'Dump tab: 45 divine (up from 38 divine yesterday)'. Helps players see their wealth accumulation. Store in a local database.
Track and display price trends over time. Help users understand market movements and make better trading decisions.
Store historical price snapshots for items over time (hourly or per-refresh from poe2scout). Build a local time-series database (SQLite or JSONL). Enables trend analysis and alerts.

Display up/down/stable trend arrows next to prices in the overlay based on 24h price movement. Green up-arrow if price increased 10%+; red down-arrow if decreased 10%+; dash if stable. Quick visual signal for buy/sell decisions.

A standalone view (console or GUI) showing: top movers (biggest price changes); most expensive items; currency exchange rate trends; chaos:divine:exalted ratio over time. Useful for market-savvy players.
Let users watchlist specific items and get notified when prices cross thresholds. E.g. 'Alert me when Divine Orbs drop below 20 chaos'. Show as overlay notification or system tray popup.
Connect with Path of Building and build planners to provide build-aware item evaluation.
Import the user's current build from a PoB pastebin or .xml file. Extract: equipped gear; skill gems; passive tree. Use this to understand which stats the player values most.

When a build is imported adjust mod weights based on what the build actually uses. E.g. a cold DoT build values +cold damage over time multiplier much more than a generic weight table suggests. Override the default mod_database weights with build-specific values.

Compare scanned items against currently equipped gear from the imported build. Highlight when a dropped item is a direct upgrade: 'Upgrade! +15% more DPS than equipped weapon'. Requires build DPS/EHP calculation or PoB integration.
Streamline the trading experience with whisper generation; listing helpers; and trade history.

After pricing an item via the trade API offer a 'copy whisper' option that generates the standard POE2 trade whisper message for the cheapest comparable listing. Copy to clipboard with a hotkey (e.g. Ctrl+Shift+W).

When the user wants to sell an item suggest an asking price based on the trade API results. Show: undercut price (sell fast); market price (fair); premium price (if top rolls). Help players who don't know what to list for.

Keep a running log of all items price-checked in the current session. Show as a scrollable list in a separate window or console view. Include: item name; grade; price; timestamp. Useful for reviewing what you've scanned.

Support pricing bulk currency trades: 'I have 500 Jeweller's Orbs — what are they worth in Divine?'. Use poe.ninja exchange rates for instant bulk valuation. Show in overlay when hovering currency stacks.
Deep item analysis features for experienced players: crafting advice; corruption analysis; and item comparison.

For rare items with open affixes suggest next crafting steps: 'Slam for life prefix' or 'Annul the mana suffix'. Use the mod_database tier data to identify which mods are worth keeping vs removing. Show in expanded overlay mode.

For unique items show the value range of corruption outcomes: implicit swap values; 6-link chance; brick to rare risk. Use trade API data for corrupted variants. Help players decide whether to Vaal an item.

Side-by-side comparison of two items: scan item A then item B and see a comparison overlay showing which mods are better/worse; DPS/defense difference; and price difference. Useful for choosing between two drops.

Detect items that are near-perfect rolls across all mods (T1 in 5+ mods with high rolls). Show a special indicator: 'Near-mirror tier' with an estimated mirror-service price. These items are worth far more than the sum of their mods.
Improve startup time; memory usage; error recovery; and offline capability. Ensure the tool is rock-solid for daily use.

Profile and optimize the startup sequence. Currently loads price cache; trade stats; mod parser; mod database; and calibration serially. Parallelize independent loads. Target: under 5 seconds from launch to 'Ready'.

When poe2scout; poe.ninja; or the trade API are down the tool should continue working with cached data and clearly indicate staleness. Show 'Cached prices (2h old)' instead of failing. Currently a failed refresh may leave stale data without warning.

Support fully offline operation using last-known cached prices and local mod scoring. Useful for SSF players or when internet is unstable. Local scoring already works offline — extend price_cache to serve stale data gracefully.

Summary: Migrate debug archive to network store
Description: Currently debug archives are stored locally in archive/ and are .gitignore'd. Migrate to a network-accessible store (S3; Azure Blob; or a simple file server) so archives can be shared across machines and with collaborators for debugging.

Summary: Add memory usage profiling and limits
Description: Profile memory usage during long sessions (4+ hours). The price cache; trade cache; calibration data; and mod database all grow over time. Add cache size limits and eviction policies. Log memory usage in status reports.

When a component crashes (e.g. trade thread exception; overlay error) attempt to restart it automatically instead of requiring a full app restart. Add a watchdog thread that monitors component health.
Prepare the project for public release and community engagement. Covers GitHub releases; documentation; contribution guide; and monetization.

Summary: Set up GitHub releases with versioned binaries
Description: Create tagged releases on GitHub with PyInstaller-bundled executables. Users can download a single .exe or .zip without installing Python. Set up a release workflow in GitHub Actions.
Create CONTRIBUTING.md with: project setup instructions; coding standards; PR process; how to run tests; architecture overview for new contributors. Lower the barrier for community contributions.

Summary: Add Buy Me a Coffee integration
Description: Add a subtle 'Support this project' link in the settings UI and README that connects to Buy Me a Coffee or GitHub Sponsors. Should be completely unobtrusive — never shown in the overlay during gameplay.
Create a Discord server for users: channels for support; bug reports; feature requests; and development discussion. Bug reporter already posts to Discord — extend with a community-facing server.

Collect anonymized usage data (items scanned per session; grades distribution; feature usage; crash reports) to guide development priorities. Must be opt-in with clear privacy explanation. No item data or account info.
Auto-generate changelogs from git commit history or PR descriptions for each release. Could use conventional commits format or a GitHub Action that compiles PR titles into CHANGELOG.md.

Refactor the POE2 overlay into a game-agnostic platform with a plugin/adapter architecture. The core engine handles overlay rendering; input monitoring; caching; and rate limiting. Game-specific logic (item parsing; trade APIs; mod scoring) lives in swappable adapters. This is the foundation for multi-game support.

Separate the overlay rendering (overlay.py) into a standalone module with no POE2-specific logic. The engine should accept: text; tier/color; position; animation config. Games provide display data; the engine renders it. Support theming so each game adapter can style the overlay differently.

Design and implement the adapter protocol/ABC that each game must implement: parse_item(clipboard_text) -> Item; score_item(item) -> Score; lookup_price(item) -> Price; get_trade_url(item) -> str; get_window_title() -> str; get_currency_types() -> list. Document the contract clearly.

Refactor the current codebase into the first game adapter. Move all POE2-specific code (item_parser; mod_parser; mod_database; trade_client; price_cache; filter_updater) into a poe2/ adapter package that implements the game adapter interface. Core engine imports it as a plugin.

Summary: Build plugin discovery and loading system
Description: Implement a plugin loader that discovers game adapters at startup. Options: entry_points (setuptools); directory-based discovery (adapters/*.py); or explicit config. Support loading multiple adapters simultaneously for users who play multiple games.

Define a game-agnostic Item data model that all adapters produce. Core fields: name; rarity; item_class; mods (list of Mod objects); stats (DPS/defense/etc); metadata. Game-specific fields go in an extras dict. This model is what the core engine operates on.

Extract the caching layer (price_cache; trade API cache; stat cache) into a shared module parameterized by game. Support: in-memory LRU; disk persistence; TTL configuration; cache warming; and size limits. Each adapter declares its cache needs.

Extract the adaptive rate limiter from trade_client.py into a shared module. Support multiple rate limit windows per API; header-based discovery; proactive backoff; and per-game configuration. Critical for any game with trade API rate limits.

On startup (or in settings) let the user select which game(s) to activate. Auto-detect running games and suggest the right adapter. Support running multiple adapters simultaneously (e.g. POE2 + Last Epoch both installed).

Build a Last Epoch adapter for the pricing platform. Last Epoch has a trade marketplace (Merchant's Guild) with a public-ish API; item affixes with tiers; and a community price tracking ecosystem (lastepochtools.com).

Summary: Research Last Epoch item data format
Description: Investigate how Last Epoch exposes item data: clipboard format (if any); chat links; trade API item schema; affix/prefix/suffix system; crafting tiers. Identify the equivalent of POE2's clipboard Ctrl+C. Last Epoch may require screen capture + OCR or memory reading (check TOS).

Implement parse_item() for Last Epoch. Handle: unique items; exalted items; set items; rare items with affixes. Map Last Epoch's affix tiers (T1-T7) to a scoring system. Handle sealed affixes and crafting potential.

Integrate with lastepochtools.com or the Merchant's Guild API for price data. Build a price cache similar to POE2's poe2scout integration. Handle Last Epoch's currency system (gold + faction standing).

Summary: Build Last Epoch mod scoring engine
Description: Score Last Epoch items based on affix tiers and synergies. Last Epoch has 7 affix tiers (T1 worst to T7 best in crafting; reversed for drops). Build tier ladders from game data. Factor in class-specific value (Sentinel affixes worth more to Sentinel players).
Build a Diablo 4 adapter for the pricing platform. D4 has no official trade API but has community tools and a seasonal economy. Item affixes have tiers and greater affixes are premium.

Investigate how to access D4 item data: no clipboard copy exists natively. Options: screenshot + OCR of item tooltips; community API endpoints; third-party tools that expose item data. Check Blizzard TOS carefully. D4's seasonal model means item data formats may change frequently.

Implement parse_item() for Diablo 4. Handle: legendary items; unique items; greater affixes; tempering; masterworking tiers. D4's affix system is simpler than POE2 but greater affixes add significant complexity.

Score D4 items based on affix quality. Greater affixes are premium; masterworking upgrades add value; tempering results matter. Build a scoring system that understands class-specific value (different affixes matter for different builds).
Build a WoW adapter for the pricing platform. WoW has the Auction House API (Blizzard API); TSM (TradeSkillMaster) price data; and a mature economy. Focus on crafted gear; consumables; and BoE items.

Summary: Research WoW Auction House API integration
Description: Investigate Blizzard's AH API: authentication (OAuth); rate limits; data freshness; regional endpoints. Also evaluate TSM's API/addon data as an alternative price source. WoW items are identified by item_id + bonus_ids which is very different from POE2's text-based system.
Integrate with Blizzard AH API and/or TSM for price data. Handle: realm-specific pricing; regional averages; historical pricing. WoW's economy is server-specific unlike POE2's league-wide economy.

Score WoW crafted gear based on item level; optional reagent choices; and embellishment slots. Factor in craft quality (1-5 stars) and resourcefulness procs. Different from POE2's mod-tier system but similar in concept.

Build a developer-facing SDK/framework that makes it easy to create game overlays. Package the core overlay engine; input monitoring; caching; and plugin system as a reusable library. Other developers can build their own game-specific tools on top.

Define the public API that developers interact with: GameOverlay class; Adapter protocol; CacheManager; RateLimiter; InputMonitor; OverlayRenderer. Write API documentation with usage examples. Keep it minimal and opinionated — don't expose internal complexity.

Restructure the project so the core engine is pip-installable: gaming-overlay-sdk on PyPI. Game adapters are separate packages (gaming-overlay-poe2; gaming-overlay-lastepoch). Use proper Python packaging (pyproject.toml; src layout).

Create a minimal example adapter that demonstrates the SDK: a simple overlay that shows item names and fake prices for a hypothetical game. Serves as the 'hello world' for SDK developers. Include in docs/examples/.

Support multiple rendering backends beyond tkinter: PyQt/PySide (richer widgets; better DPI support); DirectX overlay (lower latency; game-native feel); Electron/web-based (cross-platform; rich UI). Adapter selects backend based on game requirements.

Current input monitoring uses Win32 APIs (GetAsyncKeyState; keybd_event; GetCursorPos). Abstract behind a platform interface and add Linux support (X11/Wayland) and macOS support (Quartz). Critical for cross-platform SDK.

Comprehensive docs: getting started guide; adapter development tutorial; API reference; architecture overview; deployment guide. Host on GitHub Pages or ReadTheDocs. Include cookbook recipes for common patterns.

Pre-built UI components for common overlay patterns: price tag; grade badge; progress bar; mini-chart (sparkline); icon+text combo; tooltip panel; notification toast. Developers compose these instead of building from scratch.
Build shared data infrastructure that serves all game adapters: centralized price history; cross-game analytics; user portfolio tracking; and market intelligence. Could evolve into a hosted service.

Define a universal schema for storing price data across games: item_id; game; realm/league; price; currency; timestamp; source. Support multiple price sources per item. Use SQLite locally with option to migrate to PostgreSQL for hosted service.

Replace the scattered JSONL files (calibration.jsonl; bug_reports.jsonl) with a proper local SQLite database. Tables: items_scanned; price_history; calibration_samples; user_settings; session_stats. Enables rich querying and dashboards.

Track items found and sold per session. Show: total estimated value found; items by grade; most valuable drop; estimated chaos/hour. Persist across sessions for long-term tracking. Works across all games via the universal item model.
A standalone dashboard showing wealth across all supported games: POE2 stash value; Last Epoch stash value; WoW AH listings. Unified view of gaming portfolio. Could be a local GUI or a web dashboard.
Explore sustainable revenue models that keep the core tool free while funding development. Covers premium features; hosted services; and sponsorships.

Identify features that could be premium (paid) without making the free tier feel crippled. Candidates: cross-game support; cloud price history; advanced analytics; priority API access; custom overlay themes. The core single-game pricing must remain free.

Evaluate offering a hosted API that aggregates price data across games and serves it to third-party tools. Revenue via API key tiers (free: 100 req/day; pro: 10k req/day; enterprise: unlimited). Requires infrastructure investment.

Set up tiered sponsorship with meaningful benefits: Supporter ($3/mo) = name in credits; Pro ($10/mo) = early access to new game adapters; Patron ($25/mo) = vote on feature priority. Keep it sustainable not exploitative.
